statement.title: Problem Description
statement.content:
Goffi is doing his math homework and he finds an equality on his text book: \(\gcd(n - a, n) \times \gcd(n - b, n) = n^k\).

Goffi wants to know the number of (\(a, b\)) satisfy the equality, if \(n\) and \(k\) are given and \(1 \le a, b \le n\).

Note: \(\gcd(a, b)\) means greatest common divisor of \(a\) and \(b\).

statement.title: Input
statement.content: Input contains multiple test cases (less than 100). For each test case, there's one line containing two integers \(n\) and \(k\) (\(1 \le n, k \le 10^9\)).

statement.title: Output
statement.content: For each test case, output a single integer indicating the number of (\(a, b\)) modulo \(10^9+7\).

statement.title: Sample Output
statement.content:
2
1

Hint

For the first case, (2, 1) and (1, 2) satisfy the equality.
